verb.description: Be unsuccessful in achieving one's goal.
examples: he failed in his attempt to secure election
they failed to be ranked in the top ten
the firm failed to give adequate risk warnings

verb.description: Break down; cease to work well.
examples: a truck whose brakes had failed

noun.description: A grade that is not high enough to pass an examination or test.

phrases: he caused a stir earlier this month when he said that no company was too big to fail
For decades, governments across the West have permitted the creation of moral hazard in the banking system by encouraging the belief that banks are too big to fail.
Today, leveraged speculation has become "too big to fail."
And the greater the accumulation of foreign liabilities, the more the Monetary Regime became "too big to fail."
This environment is bringing new meaning to the doctrine of "Too Big to Fail."
origin: Middle English: from Old French faillir (verb), faille (noun), based on Latin fallere deceive.
